moves.24. Bxg5 Qxg5: I get the Bishop. White spends the next several moves threatening my Queen in different ways.
moves.25. h4 Qf6 26. g5 Qf5 27. Bh3 Qf7 28. Rg: White probably intended to do pawn to g6 on the next turn and threaten my queen again.
moves.35. Rd3: White forgets that my Bishop can attack that square, probably too focused on attacking the knight.
moves.37. Kd2 O-O-O: Trying to move my other Rook into play
moves.40. Rg1 Nxc4+: Although I took a material loss on this move, it did something very important: forced White to take my knight with the pawn and opening up a line of attack on the King. If White had simply moved the King away, I would have gotten the Queen, so it was basically a win-win situation.
moves.43. Kxe3 Re8+: From this point on, the game is mine.
moves.48. Ke1 Rgh6 49. f4 Rh2h1: Pinning White's rook and forcing him to trade it
moves.50. Rxh1 Rxh1+ 51. Kf2 Rh4: Trying to get rid of the last few pawns
moves.52. Ke3 Kd7 53. Ke4 Kd6 54. Kf5 b5: Forcing a trade of the White pawn
moves.58. f6 Re8 59. Kg7 c3 60. f7 Rd8: White basically has no more options left. He can't move his pawn forward to promote it because then the Rook can take it. The King can't threaten the rook to force it to move because my king guards the key squares. (White's king could only threaten my rook on e7 or c7, neither of which are open due to the position of my king.)
moves.61. f8=Q+: White is out of options here. One avenue left for White would be to try and force a stalemate, but since I've lost games by stalemate in similar situations, I don't want that to happen again.
moves.64. Kd8 Qg5+ 65. Kc8: Although there are ten or so turns here that I spend promoting my pawn and moving the two Queens into position to mate, I've played it through and found that it would take almost the same amount of time to force a mate with just my king, pawns, and one queen.
moves.65... c4 66. Kb7: White trying to take my pawn
moves.73... Qc8c4+ 74. Ka5 Qa3+ 75. Kb6 Qac5+: Mate. After reviewing the game, I've found that White made crucial errors in leaving his pieces unguarded and not considering the potential of all the positions on the board.
